bullets.text: U.S. real GDP surged 4.3% in Q3 2025 (initial estimate), highlighting strong growth momentum; corporate profits also reported in the same release.
Fed released guidance on how delayed G.17 industrial data for Sep–Nov 2025 affects industrial production and capacity utilization estimates; revisions risk.
October and November 2025 G.17 industrial data are now available, improving visibility into manufacturing trends after publication delays.
Fed approved National Bank Holdings Corporation’s application, signaling regulatory clearance for an expansion/transaction in the banking sector.
Fed chair candidate Kevin Hassett argues the U.S. is “behind the curve” on rate cuts, increasing uncertainty around the 2026 policy path.
U.S. to resume seizing pay of defaulted student-loan borrowers starting January, raising household cash-flow stress and potential consumer spending headwinds.
Trump administration actions reportedly paralyzed Venezuelan oil exports and the U.S. is adding to its Caribbean military buildup, escalating regional pressure.
U.S. extended additional tariffs on Chinese chips to June 2027, reinforcing long-run tech decoupling and supply-chain reshoring incentives.
Gold hit fresh records, crossing $4,500, signaling heightened demand for inflation/geopolitical hedges and potentially looser-real-rate expectations.
Trump halted offshore wind projects; analysts warn the pause could last weeks to months, increasing U.S. renewable project risk and financing uncertainty.
ServiceNow agreed to acquire cybersecurity startup Armis for $7.75B, underscoring consolidation and rising spend on enterprise security and AI-era risk management.
Aflac says hackers stole personal and health data for 22.6 million people, highlighting systemic cyber risk and potential regulatory, legal, and remediation costs.
Hackers stole over $2.7B in crypto in 2025, reinforcing security and custody weaknesses that may accelerate regulation and institutional risk controls.
U.S. approved two additional antibiotics for gonorrhea, improving treatment options amid rising resistance and potentially lowering public-health and economic burdens.
Researchers developed a fish-inspired filter removing over 99% of microplastics, a potential step-change for water treatment and environmental remediation.
